ratingsystems.Elo module

class ratingsystems.Elo.Elo_Rating(init_rating, k)

Bases: Rating

class ratingsystems.Elo.Elo_System(init_rating=1200, k=30, draw_margin=10, **_)

Bases: RatingSystem

The rating system created by Arpad Elo in the 1960s.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elo_rating_system

Here it was extended to rate players within teams, allow multi-team game formats, and predict the probability of draws.

Parameters:

  • init_rating (float) – Rating given to new players.

  • k (float) – K factor used to calculate rating updates.

  • draw_margin (float) – Margin used to predict draws. Can be thought of as the rating of a player that plays against every team (and if it wins it’s a draw).

add_game(game)

All of the systems implemented attempt to standardize the game dict provided, but to be safe it’s recommended to follow the standard format:

{
"Teams":[{
    "group1name":{
        "p1name":weight, 
        "p2name":weight
    }, 
    "group2name":{
        "p3name":weight, 
        "p4name":weight
    }
    }, 
    {
    "group1name":{
        "p5name":weight, 
        "p6name":weight
    }, 
    "group2name":{
        "p7name":weight, 
        "p9name":weight
    }
}, 
...], 
"Results": [1,0,...],
}

More keys are allowed, although as of now the only system using any beyond these ones are Glicko and Glicko2.

Parameters:

game (dict) – Dictionary with the data of a single game.

ratingsystems.Glicko module

class ratingsystems.Glicko.Glicko_Rating(init_rating, init_RD, c_sqr, k_rating, k_var)

Bases: Rating

property RD
class ratingsystems.Glicko.Glicko_System(init_rating=1500, init_RD=350, c=10, k_rating=1, k_var=1, draw_margin=1, **_)

Bases: RatingSystem

The rating system created by Mark Glickman in the 1990s.

It builds on Elo by accounting for measurement uncertainty.

http://www.glicko.net/glicko.html

Here it was extended to rate players within teams, allow multi-team game formats, and predict the probability of draws.

That said, the implementation in this package doesn’t perform very well since the ideal rating should include 5-10 games and here ratings are updated after every game.

As an attempt to compensate for this, two “k” parameters were added that scale the updates in rating and RD.

Parameters:

  • init_rating (float) – Rating given to new players.

  • init_RD (float) – RD given to new players.

  • c (float) – Increase in uncertainty between games.

  • k_rating (float) – K factor that scales the rating updates.

  • k_var (float) – K factor that scales the RD updates (more accurately, the variance updates).

  • draw_margin (float) – Margin used to predict draws. Can be thought of as the rating of a player that plays against every team (and if it wins it’s a draw).

add_game(game)

All of the systems implemented attempt to standardize the game dict provided, but to be safe it’s recommended to follow the standard format:

{
"Teams":[{
    "group1name":{
        "p1name":weight, 
        "p2name":weight
    }, 
    "group2name":{
        "p3name":weight, 
        "p4name":weight
    }
    }, 
    {
    "group1name":{
        "p5name":weight, 
        "p6name":weight
    }, 
    "group2name":{
        "p7name":weight, 
        "p9name":weight
    }
}, 
...], 
"Results": [1,0,...],
}

More keys are allowed, although as of now the only system using any beyond these ones are Glicko and Glicko2.

Parameters:

ratingsystems.Glicko2 module

class ratingsystems.Glicko2.Glicko2_Rating(init_rating, init_RD, init_sigma, tau, k_rating, k_var)

Bases: Rating

property RD
property sigma
class ratingsystems.Glicko2.Glicko2_System(init_rating=0, init_RD=2, init_sigma=0.06, tau=0.2, k_rating=1, k_var=1, draw_margin=1, **_)

Bases: RatingSystem

The rating system created by Mark Glickman in the 2000s.

It builds on Glicko by varying the rate at which RDs decrease over time.

http://www.glicko.net/glicko.html

Here it was extended to rate players within teams, allow multi-team game formats, and predict the probability of draws.

That said, the implementation in this package doesn’t perform very well since the ideal rating should include 5-10 games and here ratings are updated after every game.

As an attempt to compensate for this, two “k” parameters were added that scale the updates in rating and RD.

Parameters:

  • init_rating (float) – Rating given to new players.

  • init_RD (float) – RD given to new players.

  • init_sigma (float) – Volatility given to new players.

  • tau (float) – Constraint on how much volatility is allowed to change per game.

  • k_rating (float) – K factor that scales the rating updates.

  • k_var (float) – K factor that scales the RD updates (more accurately, the variance updates).

  • draw_margin (float) – Margin used to predict draws. Can be thought of as the rating of a player that plays against every team (and if it wins it’s a draw).

add_game(game)

All of the systems implemented attempt to standardize the game dict provided, but to be safe it’s recommended to follow the standard format:

"Teams":[{
    "group1name":{
        "p1name":weight, 
        "p2name":weight
    }, 
    "group2name":{
        "p3name":weight, 
        "p4name":weight
    }
    }, 
    {
    "group1name":{
        "p5name":weight, 
        "p6name":weight
    }, 
    "group2name":{
        "p7name":weight, 
        "p9name":weight
    }
}, 
...], 
"Results": [1,0,...],
}

More keys are allowed, although as of now the only system using any beyond these ones are Glicko and Glicko2.

Parameters:

game (dict) – Dictionary with the data of a single game.

ratingsystems.JRS module

class ratingsystems.JRS.JRS_Rating(init_mu, init_sigma, k_mu, k_lnvar, dynamic_start, final_psi, psi_decay)

Bases: Rating

property J_Consistency

Base 2 log of the square root of performance precision adjusted for rating drifts.

property J_Skill

Average performance adjusted for rating drifts.

property J_Uncertainty

Same as psi.

property J_XE

Probability of outperforming the average active participant.

property lnvar

Natural log of the performance variance.

property psi

Current step size multiplier.

property sigma

Performance standard deviation.

class ratingsystems.JRS.JRS_System(draw_margin=1, init_mu=0, init_sigma=1, k_mu=0.1, k_lnvar=0.1, final_psi=0.5, psi_decay=0.05, avg_decay=0.01, dynamic_start=[], **_)

Bases: RatingSystem

The rating system created by Jayensee in 2024.

It uses gradient descent to estimate both the average and variance of the performance exhibited by rated participants. The step size decreases with the number of games player by the participant.

Ratings are continuously adjusted such that the average active participant has a J-Skill of 0 and J-Consistency of 1 (to avoid the ratings drifting over time).

New players have their initial average performance set to the average of the rated participants in their first match.

Parameters:

  • init_mu (float) – Initial performance average for new participants when none of the groups in dynamic_start are present in the match.

  • init_sigma (float) – Initial performance standard deviation for new participants.

  • k_mu (float) – Initial step size for updates to the performance average.

  • k_lnvar (float) – Initial step size for updates to the log of the performance variance.

  • final_psi (float) – Multiplier for the step size of a participant with infinite games.

  • psi_decay (float) – Rate at which the step size decays.

  • avg_decay (float) – Rate at which the estimation of the average rating changes.

  • dynamic_start (list[str]) – List of groups to include when initializing ratings.

  • draw_margin (float) – Minimum performance difference required for a victory.

property adjusted_draw_margin

ratingsystems.Metrics module

The Metrics module contains all of the metric classes that can be used with the rating systems.

Every metric class has an error attribute that can be used as the loss for minimization.

Note: every rating system is assumed to predict draw probabilities.

class ratingsystems.Metrics.GMeanLikelihood(name='GMeanLikelihood')

Bases: object

The geometric mean of the likelihood.

Can be thought of as the likelihood for each match.

class ratingsystems.Metrics.GMeanLikelihood_Log_Odds(name='GMeanLikelihood_Log_Odds')

Bases: GMeanLikelihood

Log-odds of the geometric mean of the likelihood.

Transforms the geometric mean of the likelihood to have no upper or lower bound.

class ratingsystems.Metrics.InformationPreempted(name='InformationPreempted', draw_margin=0)

Bases: object

The information content not preempted by the system for each head to head match is given by the average negative log likelihood of its predictions.

By subtracting this amount from the theoretical maximum information limit of 1 trit/bit we get the average information the system already had before knowing the outcome of each match.

The unit used is the bit.

class ratingsystems.Metrics.PercentInformationPreempted(name='PercentInformationPreempted', draw_margin=0)

Bases: object

Since every game is split into a series of head to head matches, there are 3 possible outcomes for each of these: win, draw, or loss (two if draws aren’t possible).

This means that each outcome can carry up to 1 trit/bit of information.

The information preempted by the system is divided by the maximum theoretical information (1 trit/bit) and multiplied by 100 to get the percentage of this maximum that the system preempted.

class ratingsystems.Metrics.RMS_Score_Error(name='RMS_Score_Error')

Bases: object

Root mean square error of the score.

The score is defined as 1 for a win, 0.5 for a draw, 0 for a loss.

ratingsystems.OpenSkill module

class ratingsystems.OpenSkill.OpenSkill_Rating(init_mu, init_sigma)

Bases: Rating, ThurstoneMostellerFullRating

property std
property var
class ratingsystems.OpenSkill.OpenSkill_System(init_mu=25, init_sigma=8.3, beta=4.2, tau=0.083, kappa=0.0001, draw_margin=0.1, **_)

Bases: RatingSystem

An open source system developed as an alternative to TrueSkill.

It functions very similarly to TrueSkill but without patented mechanisms (mainly the factor graphs).

https://openskill.me/en/stable/

As with TrueSkill, this implementation doesn’t doesn’t fully support rating groups as well as repeated participants on different teams or 0-weight participants.

Parameters:

  • init_mu (float) – Initial performance average for new participants.

  • init_sigma (float) – Initial measurement uncertainty.

  • beta (float) – Performance standard deviation of all participants.

  • tau (float) – Dynamic factor which accounts for change in performance over time.

  • kappa (float) – A very small number to limit how low the standards deviations are allowed to fall.

  • draw_margin (float) – Minimum performance difference required for a victory.

class ratingsystems.RatingSystem.Participant(system, group, name, rating_class, **params)

Bases: object

This is the class used for every participant (regular or interaction).

It shouldn’t need to be extended, and ParticipantGroup objects should only be created through the methods in the RatingSystem class.

class ratingsystems.RatingSystem.ParticipantGroup(system, name, rating_class, **group_params)

Bases: object

This is used for regular participant groups.

It shouldn’t need to be extended, and ParticipantGroup objects should only be created through the methods in the RatingSystem class.

class ratingsystems.RatingSystem.Rating(**rating_params)

Bases: object

This is the base Rating class that needs to be extended for every rating system.

Rating objects are created by the Participant class and have their parent Participant, ParticipantGroup, and System objects automatically added as attributes.

The recent_partials attribute is also automatically updated and keeps track of the weights associated with the rating in the current game (it’s a dictionary with teamind: weight pairs for every team that the Participant is a part of).

Ratings have a __hash__ method so they can be used as keys in dictionaries.

Parameters:

rating_params (dict) – Keyword parameters used by the Rating.

class ratingsystems.RatingSystem.RatingSystem(rating_class, **default_params)

Bases: object

This is the base class every rating system inherits from. It includes all the core methods and attributes that are used by most (if not all) systems.

It’s not an actual rating system in itself, it only exists to be inherited.

Parameters:

  • rating_class (Rating) – The rating class used by the system. Every system implemented is expected to have its own rating class.

  • default_params (dict) – The default parameters for new ratings. These get passed onto the rating objects when they’re created, so make sure the rating class accepts them.

Adds a metric to the rating system.

calc_prediction_matrix(game_full, h2h_ratings=None)

Calculates the predictions for a given game.

Returns a square matrix with the [win, draw, loss] probabilities at of team i vs team j at (i,j).

Parameters:

  • game_full (dict) – Dictionary with the data of a single game (including interactions).

  • h2h_ratings (list[list[Rating]]) – Nested lists (i, j) with the ratings of team i vs team j.

Returns:

Prediction matrix.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

group_name (str) – Name of the rating group.

Parameters:

print_participants()

Prints the ratings of all participants to stdout.

set_group(name, **override_params)

Creates a new rating group and sets its rating params. If the group already exists it just sets the rating params.

Parameters:

  • group_name (dict) – Name of the rating group.

  • override_params – The rating parameters of the group.

set_interaction(group1_name, group2_name, same_team, **override_params)

Creates a new interaction rating group of the given groups and sets its rating params. If the group already exists it just sets the rating params.

Parameters:

  • group1_name (str) – The name of the first group.

  • group2_name (str) – The name of the second group.

  • same_team (bool) – True if the interaction consists of ally duos or matchups with opponents.

  • override_params – The rating parameters of the group.

ratingsystems.TrueSkill module

class ratingsystems.TrueSkill.TrueSkill_Rating(init_mu, init_sigma)

Bases: Rating, Rating

property mu

A property which returns the mean.

property sigma

A property which returns the the square root of the variance.

property std
property var
class ratingsystems.TrueSkill.TrueSkill_System(init_mu=25, init_sigma=8.3, beta=4.2, tau=0.083, draw_margin=0, **_)

Bases: RatingSystem

The rating system created by Microsoft in 2005.

It models matches using factor graphs and uses Gaussian density filtering to estimate the parameters of the graphs. Each rating consists of the average performance and the measurement uncertainty, every player is assumed to have the same performance standard deviation.

It extended the core principles behind Elo to work for multi-player teams, multi-team games, and to predict draw probabilities.

https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/publication/trueskilltm-a-bayesian-skill-rating-system/

This package uses the implementation by Heungsub Lee and doesn’t fully support rating groups as well as repeated participants on different teams or 0-weight participants.

Note: Microsoft has a patent on using factor graphs for rating systems, so make sure you’re legally allowed to use this system before using it.

Parameters:

  • init_mu (float) – Initial performance average for new participants.

  • init_sigma (float) – Initial measurement uncertainty.

  • beta (float) – Performance standard deviation of all participants.

  • tau (float) – Dynamic factor which accounts for change in performance over time.

  • draw_margin (float) – Minimum performance difference required for a victory.

All of the systems implemented attempt to standardize the game dict provided, but to be safe it’s recommended to follow the standard format:
